acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Not classified from 96 hours LC50>100mg/L of the fish (Oryzias Latipest) (MOE eco-toxicity tests of chemicals (2001) and others.).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (dermal route) of 10,600 mg/kg (CICAD 45 (2002)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "liquid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) of 4,000-10,200mg/kg (CICAD 45 (2002)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category A4 by ACGIH (2001).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since it was not water-insolubility (the water-solubility =1.00*106mg/L (PHYSPROP Database, 2005)), and acute toxicity was low, it was classified into Not classified.

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the negative data on rat dominant lethal tests, absence of data on germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo, and the negative data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (chromosome aberration tests/micronucleus tests), described in CICAD 45 (2002).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing oxygen (but not fluorine and chlorine), with the oxygen bound to carbon and hydrogen (but not to other elements)

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Not pyrophoric when in contact with air at ordinary temperatures: the auto-ignition temperature is 398degC (ICSC, 2000)

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: May damage fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Based on the description in the report on mouse continuous breeding and rat teratogenicity tetss (CICAD 45 (2002)): Malformations, retarded ossification and unossification are observed in offspring at dosing levels not toxic to dams.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (CICAD 45 (2002)): Short-term exposure to ethylene glycol (liquid or vapour) causes conjunctival irritation with no permanent damage to the cornea.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on rabbit and guinea pig skin irritation tests (CICAD 45 (2002)): "mild dermal irritation in rabbits and guinea pigs."

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.classification: Category 1 (central nervous system, respiratory system, heart)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (central nervous system, respiratory system, heart)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on human evidence including "loss of consciousness and nystagmus," "mild headache and backache, upper respiratory tract irritation" (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 3 (2004)), and the evidence from animal studies including "inflammatory degeneration of the lung and heart" (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 3 (2004) The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.classification: Category 1 (central nervous system, kidney, heart, respiratory system)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (central nervous system, kidney, heart, respiratory system)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including: "consciousness disorder, convulsions and stupor (after 34 days of accidental ingestion); an increase in urea nitrogen, creatinine and uric acid concentrations (blood examination); albuminuria, hematuria and nephropathy (urine examination); degeneration of convoluted tubules (renal biopsy); mild pulmonary congestion," "acute effects are observed in four stages: effects on the central nervous system (after 0.5-12 hours of exposure); effects on the heart-lung system (after 12-36 hours of exposure); nephropathy in specimens surviving from Stage 1 and 2 (exposure to ethylene glycol); degeneration of the central nervous system" (CERI Hazard Data 97-24 (1998)).
